item.title: FlowerGame Logs
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Actually, all the code I wrote works because I tested it in an environment.

Not to be offensive here, but you’re just adding it incorrectly.

src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:58: error: ';' expected String filePath = "./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/", Player.getPlayerName() + ".txt"; ^
Your first error is because you have a comma where you need to place a plus sign.

src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:58: error: not a statement String filePath = "./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/", Player.getPlayerName() + ".txt";
Your second error is because of the first error.

src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:28: error: cannot find symbol if(player == null) ^ symbol: variable player location: class FlowerLog
The variable “player” is not defined, therefore it’s causing an error. Notice how in my method I defined the player variable as “p”.

File f = new File("./data/"); ^ symbol: class File location: class FlowerLog src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:31: error: cannot find symbol File f = new File("./data/"); ^ symbol: class File location: class FlowerLog src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:35: error: cannot find symbol f = new File("./data/saves/"); ^ symbol: class File location: class FlowerLog src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:39: error: cannot find symbol f = new File("./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/"); ^ symbol: class File location: class FlowerLog src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:43: error: cannot find symbol f = new File("./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/" + Player.getPlayerName() + ".txt"); ^ symbol: class File location: class FlowerLog
For all of these errors, you need to import the File class.

src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:43: error: non-static method getPlayerName() cannot be referenced from a static context f = new File("./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/" + Player.getPlayerName() + ".txt"); ^ src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:58: error: cannot find symbol String filePath = "./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/", Player.getPlayerName() + ".txt"; ^ symbol: method getPlayerName() location: class FlowerLog src\com\ruseps\world\content\FlowerLog.java:63: error: cannot find symbol bw.write("[" + dateFormat.format(cal.getTime()) + "] " + "[" + Player.getPlayerName() + "] " + "planted " + color); ^ symbol: method getPlayerName() location: variable Player of type String
All these errors are because you are accessing the class “Player” - and not the player object “p”.

Read full topic

Read full topic

item.title: FlowerGame Logs
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

You need to check if the file exists.

However, the thing is. You have to go 1 layer at a time to do so.

private static boolean playerHasFile(Player p) { if(player == null) return false; try { File f = new File("./data/"); if(!f.exists()) { f.mkdir(); } f = new File("./data/saves/"); if(!f.exists()) { f.mkdir(); } f = new File("./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/"); if(!f.exists()) { f.mkdir(); } f = new File("./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/" + player.getPlayerName() + ".txt"); if(!f.exists()) { f.createNewFile(); } return true; } catch(IOException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } return false; }

If you do not go layer by layer, and one of the folders does not exist, you’ll throw an IOException.

More information about Java’s File class can be found by clicking here.

Note: If you are 100% sure the files exist, and that they will not be removed, there’s no need to check for them.

Read full topic

item.title: FlowerGame Logs
item.dc:creator: @Soulxs Soulxs
item.description:
@Soulxs wrote:

Would it be possible to make a folder in the directory “saves” called FlowerPlantsLogs and make Java create a new file for every player that plants a flower if there isn’t already a file with that player name in the directory?

I’ve started but i have no idea how to get it done…
Code in FlowerLog.java:

package com.ruseps.world.content;

import com.ruseps.world.entity.impl.player.Player;
import java.io.BufferedWriter;
import java.io.FileWriter;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.text.DateFormat;
import java.text.SimpleDateFormat;
import java.util.Calendar;

public class FlowerLog {
	
	public static String getFlowerColor(int object) {
		switch (object) {
			case 2980: return "Pastel";
			case 2981: return "Red";
			case 2982: return "Blue";
			case 2983: return "Yellow";
			case 2984: return "Purple";
			case 2985: return "Orange";
			case 2986: return "Rainbow";
			case 2987: return "White";
			case 2988: return "Black";
		}
		return "error getting color";
	}
	public static void createFile {
		if (!filePath.contains(player.getUsername)) {
			// ------------This is where the code should be that tells Java to create a folder. But what code?
		}
		
	}
	
	public static void writeFlowerLog(Player player, String color)
    {
			DateFormat dateFormat = new SimpleDateFormat("yyyy/MM/dd, HH:mm:ss");
			Calendar cal = Calendar.getInstance();
            String filePath = "./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/", player.getUsername() + ".txt";
            BufferedWriter bw = null;
            try
            {
                    bw = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(filePath, true));
					bw.write("[" + dateFormat.format(cal.getTime()) + "] " + "[" + player.getPlayerName() + "]    " + "planted       " + color);
                    bw.newLine();
                    bw.flush();
            }
            catch (IOException ioe)
            {
                    ioe.printStackTrace();
            }
            finally
            {
                    if (bw != null)
                    {
                            try
                            {
                                    bw.close();
                            }
                            catch (IOException ioe2)
                            {}
                    }
            }
    }
	
	
}

I think i might already have a mistake though, because filePath is declared as:

 String filePath = "./data/saves/FlowerPlantLogs/", player.getUsername() + ".txt";

And the createFile method uses that filePath so it wouldn’t work ayways. Am i right ? If so, how do i fix that?
If anyone could help me out that would be fantastic. Thanks in advance.
Oh and by the way sk8r (or anyone who has helped me for that matter) sorry i keep asking so much. I’ve read and watched a whole lot of tutorials but it just doesn’t seem to work for me. I have to do it do learn how it works. And FYI, when i asked a question and it got awnsered i don’t just copy paste it into the file and compile. I do actually analyze it and to try and understand why it does what it does. So i do actually learn soething

Read full topic

item.title: FlowerGame Logs
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Soulxs, post:7, topic:553669”]I’ve tryed changing it to objectId but it gives me the error saying:

src\com\ruseps\world\content\Gambling.java:80: error: non-static variable objectId cannot be referenced from a static context
                FlowerLog.writeFlowerLog((Player)player, FlowerLog.getFlowerColor(FlowersData.objectId));
                                                                                             ^
1 error

so i didn’t think it was neccesary to say ^^[/quote]
That would be because you’re again using something that isn’t declared.

I did not say to use “FlowersData.objectId”.
I said to use the FlowerData object, or the GameObject object. Which you have declared as “flowers” and “flower” respectively.

To get the object id from the FlowerData object, you need to use “flowers.objectId”

item.title: FlowerGame Logs
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

It’s a single class. not a single thread or post. Try not to get your terminology confused

Your error is still because you haven’t declared the variable “object” anywhere.
As your method “getFlowerColor” requires an int, you should grab the object id from either the “FlowersData flowers” object, or from the “GameObject flower” object.

Not sure how your GameObject class works, but I’d assume you’d use similar to:

FlowerLog.writeFlowerLog((Player)player, FlowerLog.getFlowerColor(flower.getObjectId())); // or this FlowerLog.writeFlowerLog((Player)player, FlowerLog.getFlowerColor(flower.objectId));

Note, you could also clean up the code by requiring the object id as the second parameter in the writeFlowerLog method, then getting the color within that method (very minor). And you could also clean up the writeFlowerLog method by using a try-with-resources, and declaring some variables as constants (They never change, no need to initialize them each time the method is used):
Click here to view on pastebin - SMF likes to ruin formatting so it’s on pastebin.

Read full topic

item.title: FlowerGame Logs
item.dc:creator: @Soulxs Soulxs
item.description:
@Soulxs wrote:

Sorry for making a new thread, you are right. As for the error;

Code in gambling.java:

package com.ruseps.world.content;

import com.ruseps.model.Animation;
import com.ruseps.model.GameObject;
import com.ruseps.model.Graphic;
import com.ruseps.model.PlayerRights;
import com.ruseps.model.Locations.Location;
import com.ruseps.model.movement.MovementQueue;
import com.ruseps.util.Misc;
import com.ruseps.world.content.clan.ClanChatManager;
import com.ruseps.world.content.dialogue.DialogueManager;
import com.ruseps.world.entity.impl.npc.NPC;
import com.ruseps.world.entity.impl.player.Player;
import com.ruseps.world.content.FlowerLog;
//import com.ruseps.world.entity.impl.player.FlowerLog;

public class Gambling {

	public static void rollDice(Player player) {
		if(player.getRights() == PlayerRights.PLAYER) {
			player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("You need to be a member to use this item.");
			return;
		}
		if(player.getLocation() != Location.VARROCK) {
			player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("").sendMessage("This dice can only be used in the gambling area!").sendMessage("To get there, talk to the gambler.");
			return;
		}
		if(player.getClanChatName() == null) {
			player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("You need to be in a clanchat channel to roll a dice.");
			return;
		} else if(player.getClanChatName().equalsIgnoreCase("help")) {
			player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("You can't roll a dice in this clanchat channel!");
			return;
		}
		if(!player.getClickDelay().elapsed(3000)) {
			player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("You must wait 3 seconds between each dice cast.");
			return;
		}
		player.getMovementQueue().reset();
		player.performAnimation(new Animation(11900));
		player.performGraphic(new Graphic(2075));
		ClanChatManager.sendMessage(player.getCurrentClanChat(), "@bla@[ClanChat] @whi@"+player.getUsername()+" just rolled @bla@" +Misc.getRandom(100)+ "@whi@ on the percentile dice.");
		player.getClickDelay().reset();
	}

	public static void plantSeed(Player player) {
		if(player.getRights() == PlayerRights.PLAYER) {
			player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("You need to be a member to use this item.");
			return;
		}
		if(player.getLocation() != Location.VARROCK) {
			player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("").sendMessage("This seed can only be planted in the gambling area").sendMessage("To get there, talk to the gambler.");
			return;
		}
		if(!player.getClickDelay().elapsed(3000))
			return;
		for(NPC npc : player.getLocalNpcs()) {
			if(npc != null && npc.getPosition().equals(player.getPosition())) {
				player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("You cannot plant a seed right here.");
				return;
			}
		}
		if(CustomObjects.objectExists(player.getPosition().copy())) {
			player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("You cannot plant a seed right here.");
			return;
		}
		FlowersData flowers = FlowersData.generate();
		final GameObject flower = new GameObject(flowers.objectId, player.getPosition().copy());
		player.getMovementQueue().reset();
		player.getInventory().delete(299, 1);
		player.performAnimation(new Animation(827));
		player.getPacketSender().sendMessage("You plant the seed..");
		player.getMovementQueue().reset();
		player.setDialogueActionId(42);
		player.setInteractingObject(flower);
		DialogueManager.start(player, 78);
		MovementQueue.stepAway(player);
		CustomObjects.globalObjectRemovalTask(flower, 90);
		player.setPositionToFace(flower.getPosition());
		FlowerLog.writeFlowerLog((Player)player, FlowerLog.getFlowerColor(object));
		player.getClickDelay().reset();
		}

	public enum FlowersData {
		PASTEL_FLOWERS(2980, 2460),
		RED_FLOWERS(2981, 2462),
		BLUE_FLOWERS(2982, 2464),
		YELLOW_FLOWERS(2983, 2466),
		PURPLE_FLOWERS(2984, 2468),
		ORANGE_FLOWERS(2985, 2470),
		RAINBOW_FLOWERS(2986, 2472),

		WHITE_FLOWERS(2987, 2474),
		BLACK_FLOWERS(2988, 2476);
		FlowersData(int objectId, int itemId) {
			this.objectId = objectId;
			this.itemId = itemId;
		}

		public int objectId;
		public int itemId;
		
		public static FlowersData forObject(int object) {
			for(FlowersData data : FlowersData.values()) {
				if(data.objectId == object)
					return data;
			}
			return null;
		}
		
		public static FlowersData generate() {
			double RANDOM = (java.lang.Math.random() * 100);
			if(RANDOM >= 1) {
				return values()[Misc.getRandom(6)];
			} else {
				return Misc.getRandom(3) == 1 ? WHITE_FLOWERS : BLACK_FLOWERS;
			}
		}
	}
}

Code in FlowerLog.java (To have it all in 1 post):

package com.ruseps.world.content;

import com.ruseps.world.entity.impl.player.Player;
import java.io.BufferedWriter;
import java.io.FileWriter;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.text.DateFormat;
import java.text.SimpleDateFormat;
import java.util.Calendar;

public class FlowerLog {

	
	public static String getFlowerColor(int object) {
		switch (object) {
			case 2980: return "Pastel";
			case 2981: return "Red";
			case 2982: return "Blue";
			case 2983: return "Yellow";
			case 2984: return "Purple";
			case 2985: return "Orange";
			case 2986: return "Rainbow";
			case 2987: return "White";
			case 2988: return "Black";
		}
		return "error getting color";
	}
	
	public static void writeFlowerLog(Player player, String color)
    {
			DateFormat dateFormat = new SimpleDateFormat("yyyy/MM/dd, HH:mm:ss");
			Calendar cal = Calendar.getInstance();
            String filePath = "./data/saves/FlowerPlantsLog.txt";
            BufferedWriter bw = null;
            try
            {
                    bw = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(filePath, true));
					bw.write("[" + dateFormat.format(cal.getTime()) + "] " + "[" + player.getPlayerName() + "]    " + "planted       " + color);
                    bw.newLine();
                    bw.flush();
            }
            catch (IOException ioe)
            {
                    ioe.printStackTrace();
            }
            finally
            {
                    if (bw != null)
                    {
                            try
                            {
                                    bw.close();
                            }
                            catch (IOException ioe2)
                            {}
                    }
            }
    }
	
	
}

Read full topic

item.title: FlowerGame Logs
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

So, first off. Let me start out by stating this: You do not need to make a new class for everything. Honestly.

Your flower game log methods (Your whole 2 of them) should actually go into the FlowerGame class, along with the game.

And to answer your error:
I can’t directly say why it doesn’t see the variable “object”, as you did not provide the entire gambling class. You provided one line.

If you want me to answer it off one line, simple:
The variable doesn’t exist.

Read full topic

Regardless. As your topic is still clearly visible, there was no reason to make this one. The only time I personally see it’s fair to make a new duplicate, is if your topic got sent 3 pages back with 0 replies.

		final GameObject flower = new GameObject(flowers.objectId, player.getPosition().copy());

		player.getClickDelay().reset();

FlowerLog.java code:

import java.util.Calendar;

public class FlowerLog {

	
	public static String getFlowerColor(int object) {
		switch (object) {
			case 2980: return "Pastel";
			case 2981: return "Red";
			case 2982: return "Blue";

	public static void writeFlowerLog(Player player, String color)

			DateFormat dateFormat = new SimpleDateFormat("yyyy/MM/dd, HH:mm:ss");

            String filePath = "./data/saves/FlowerPlantsLog.txt";

                    bw.newLine();
                    bw.flush();
            }
            catch (IOException ioe)

item.title: FlowerGame Logs
item.dc:creator: @Soulxs Soulxs
item.description:
@Soulxs wrote:

I tried adding FlowerPoker logs to prevent scams, using this code in FlowerLog.java:

package com.ruseps.world.content;

import com.ruseps.world.entity.impl.player.Player;
import java.io.BufferedWriter;
import java.io.FileWriter;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.text.DateFormat;
import java.text.SimpleDateFormat;
import java.util.Calendar;

public class FlowerLog {

	
	public static String getFlowerColor(int object) {
		switch (object) {
			case 2980: return "Pastel";
			case 2981: return "Red";
			case 2982: return "Blue";
			case 2983: return "Yellow";
			case 2984: return "Purple";
			case 2985: return "Orange";
			case 2986: return "Rainbow";
			case 2987: return "White";
			case 2988: return "Black";
		}
		return "error getting color";
	}
	
	
	public static void writeFlowerLog(Player player, String color)
    {
			DateFormat dateFormat = new SimpleDateFormat("yyyy/MM/dd, HH:mm:ss");
			Calendar cal = Calendar.getInstance();
            String filePath = "./data/saves/FlowerPlantsLog.txt";
            BufferedWriter bw = null;
            try
            {
                    bw = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(filePath, true));
					bw.write("[" + dateFormat.format(cal.getTime()) + "] " + "[" + player.getPlayerName() + "]    " + "planted       " + color);
                    bw.newLine();
                    bw.flush();
            }
            catch (IOException ioe)
            {
                    ioe.printStackTrace();
            }
            finally
            {
                    if (bw != null)
                    {
                            try
                            {
                                    bw.close();
                            }
                            catch (IOException ioe2)
                            {}
                    }
            }
    }
	
	
}
